title: Tripod mount Canon Type A II fitting EF 200/2,8 L, EF 80-200/2,8L, EF 200/2,8 L, EF 70-200/4 L, EF 70-200/4 L IS, EF 400/5,6 L USM.

description.text:
Added main bracket with integrated Manfrotto plate into part. STL-files include support to remove after printing.
Install M6x25 with M6 lock nut in the knob turning the nut the "wrong" way on the bolt. You may need to heat the bolt/nut if fit is too tight.
The brackets are joined by a M3x16mm Allen head bolt and a lock nut. There are no threads in the holes so drill 5-5,3 mm for the M6 (knob) and the same for the 1/4" for the tripod thread. Then make threads with appropriate tap. Or, simply screw the bolts in making its own threads as I did. Had to drill slightly bigger holes though. The tripod mount fits lenses Ø65mm with maximum 17,5 mm groove for mount. I use it for a Canon EF 200/2.8 to substitute the Canon Tripod mount Type A II fitting these canon lenses:
EF 200/2,8 L USM
EF 80-200/2,8L USM
EF 200/2,8 L II USM
EF 70-200/4 L USM

remixed_from.author: Neo_Usagi
remixed_from.title: E3D v6 40 mm Fan Duct and Extruder for MakerGear M2

title: Updated E3Dv6 Shroud and 40 mm Duct w/ Magnetic Coupler

description.text: UPDATE: I've updated the parts to fit 5mm magnets. There are a separate set of parts that were labeled 5mm. In response to several requests to make assembly and disassembly of my E3Dv6 duct (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:494430) more easy, I've updated the duct and eliminated the bolts that hold the 40 mm duct to the extruder body. I've redesigned the E3D shroud to be a bit tighter with sockets for two 1/4" magnets. These can be easily found on ebay and Amazon. Once the magnets are glued in place, the ducts snap together and hold very tightly. Because the 40 mm fan duct attaches directly to the 30 mm fan shroud, this design is no longer Makergear M2 specific but a more general design. This too is to address a series of requests for a more generally applicable design. I've also posted a mirrored shroud so the 40 mm duct can be mounted on either side of the extruder. The mount is centered on the 40 mm duct so this duct can be fitted on either side of the shroud.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm & .4mm

Infill:

50-70%

Notes: I've printed these with both 0.3 and 0.4 mm nozzles. They should not require supports if the files are printed as oriented. I've been testing this update on my printer for the last month and see no change in performance, other than it is much easier to disassemble / reassemble. Because of the efficiency of the design I suggest 20-25% fan speed.

Once printed glue 1/4" magnets into the sockets. Take care to properly orient the magnets in the sockets so that the parts attract rather than repel each other.  There is a small tab under the magnet socket on the 30 mm fan shroud that should be snapped off and trimmed.

The reason I ask is because the 40mm fans tend to be quieter than the 30mm ones.  I have recently made changes to the wiring of my printer so the hot end fan only comes on when the temperature is over a set point so the noise probably won't be an issue now.
comments.author: Neo_Usagi

comments.text: I must admit that the 40mm fans are much quieter. Your experience is a bit different from mine. I didn't always encounter issues but with particular filaments, (higher temp) this was a problem. For most things like PLA and ABS (with exception of the higher melt temp ABS) this wasn't a problem. It may also be a function of the relative efficiency and voltages of our fans too. I know that there are 40mm to 30mm adapters but to my knowledge nobody has made a remix of this design to allow a 40mm fan.

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback FZS1_Fazer. I went through quite a few iterations to get the fit right and the two magnets are overkill for most casual stuff. But the reason for this is that on one print the duct got snagged on a part of a print lifting from the bed and made a huge mess - the duct melted around the hot end and also fused with other plastic coming out the hot end so made a giant ball of plastic surrounded by a nest of plastic strands. I "simulated" this and it took two magnets to prevent the duct from dislodging from its perch. So most people won't need this degree of security but I wanted to give folks (like me) that added degree of confidence.
comments.author: FZS1_Fazer

comments.text:
Of course, but I'm not sure if the power of the two N50's with doubled thickness will have not the same effect as your two pairs of thin N52's. From the mechanical point the lower position is the one where you need the magent power while the upper position is so close to the "nose" connection that the magnets there have less effect caused by lever Act.
The weight of both solutions will be the same anyway.

author: PanFX

description.text:
Designed for the Printrbot Simple Metal 1403, this alerts you when your print job is complete. X and Y are homed (quite standard end geode) and the carriage is brought up to the maximum Z, which triggers an end stop switch to alert you with a LED strobe. See video here: https://youtu.be/YYuqo9zJqr8 gcode needs to be added to your slicer's printer settings (before motors are disabled):
G1 Z152 F300 S1 ** Note: F300 is an increased motor speed so it doesn't take forever to reach there for flatter prints. BOM:
2 x M28 or M210mm screws
1 x M38mm screw
2 x M312mm screws
1 x M3*20mm screw
1 x 50mm (10mm diameter) carbon fibre rod or equivalent plug
1 x end stop switch
1 x LED Strobe light
12V wire
a couple of cable ties to hold down the wires
...and...
Multi-socket and some 2.1mm DC socket female jacks (panel mount type) >> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:948418 OR splice your 12V input to support the LED strobe. I am waiting for the arrival of recordable audio boards, to provide additional audio alerting. Installation:
The "extension" arm joins the "base" (split to fit my Printrbot's 152mm bed) with a leftover carbon fibre rod (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1149078) and both units are secured with a M3*20mm screw The "Light Holder" arm is linked with a M3*8mm screw. The end stop switch is attached to the "Endswitch Holder" with 2 x M2*8mm screws (10mm better if you have any). The "Endswitch Holder" is screwed from the bottom of the whole base, with 2 x M3*12mm screws, allowing height adjustment. Wiring:
12V source ground > strobe ground (black wire)
12v source positive lead (red wire) > end stop "C" or "1" position
Strobe positive lead > end stop "NO" (normally open) or "2" position Then sit back, relax, let your printer tell you when it's done.

title: Nespresso capsule USSS (under shelf storage system)

description.text:
This system can be used to store Nespresso capsules under a shelf. You can have the capsules hanging over the coffee machine. The holes in the holder are in an angle, so rail is tilted. This makes the capsules move to the start of the track by gravity.
You need to orient the parts before printing. Flat the rail on rotate the holder so that the holes are upwards.
Then just insert the rail to the holder and then screw the holder to the shelf.  You can put multiple units side by side. They have alignment features on the sides. 
The capsule is also included if you want to design something yourself.

If you have any difficulties assemblyng the projects drop me a message, I will answer shortly. List of changes (compared to original project by 3DSIGNUM):
  • CoreXY kinematics instead of H-Bot.
  • 8 mm leadscrew, 10 mm smooth rods on Z axis.

comments.text: It depends on things like quality of your linear bearings and printer schema. On Z-bed printers (H-bot, CoreXY) this isn't an issue since hotbed doesn't move horizontally.
comments.author: geoxile

comments.text: According to Misumi linear bearings (for rods) have a much looser fitting than linear guides. So if the hot bed is on the Z-axis it could shake across the x and y axes very slightly. Misumi's blog said something like the error being a thousandth of an inch, but that could mean up to 25 micron. Plus deflection and flex from the weight of the bed will add to it.

author: kuko4

title: Y-axis Reprap redesign with integrated PCB Heatedbed.

description.text: The Prusajrâ€™s PCB heatedbed is a very interesting commercial piece for its simplicity and performance. The problem is that it doesn't fit perfectly with the design of the Y-Axis of Reprap. Due to heat, expansion, and fixation at the four corners, the platform could reach warp. To fix this I have set the platform under an 3 mm aluminum plate to provide rigidity and protection. The platform is placed upside down, where hotter. The protection of the upside PCB is replaced by the aluminum sheet. The group is supported by two vertical pieces that together with plastic bushings Igus slide on the Y-axis guides. These vertical supports are designed to be easy to assemble and disassemble the set of PCB heatedbed and aluminum plate, in order to unload parts or perform cleanup. The belt is fixed directly to supports pieces. It has also included a threaded hole with M3 for a screw to tighten the belt easily. Redesing 6-Nov-2011 I made â€‹â€‹some modifications to work better. Added two pieces of rod 8x145 to join the uprights, has increased the height of the uprights in 5 mm, and gaps were placed to hinder the transmission of heat. I've also uploaded some photos, some can see the changes that have made my Prusa, now called Prusa Air. You can see more in: http://reprap.org/wiki/Prusa_Air

Cut the pieces on 3 mm alluminium sheet. Screw the PCB heated bed to the alluminium plate, don't tight it much. Insert the Igus clip bushings at suport pieces  screw they with M8x145 rods, washers and nuts and assemble all. We'll need kapton tape probably for separate PCB heated bed from vertical suports pieces.
You will need belt-clamp RP-pieces and M3 screws to fix the belt. If you threated the hole at suport pieces at M3 and you put a M3x20 bolt you'll get a good belt tensioner.

author: Mecano

title: Fixed bed level mounts for OLP

description.text:
Mounts to keep the level of the heated bed at a maximum of 18mm. The original springs must stay in place but the screws can be loosened. The springs keep the buildplate pushed to the 18mm mounts, so it never rises above 18mm. At the same time the springs allow downward movement to keep the printhead from destroying itself or the glass buildplate. Remarks for foto's
1) printed mounts
2) mark the spot using a 4mm drill (opposit side of spring in front of each printtower)
3) drill a 3mm hole (the biggest drill i could fit in my dremel)
4) widen to 4mm (did it by hand, the OLP's plastic is not that hard)
5&6) place the washers (18mm diameter, 1.5mm thick, 2 pieces for each mount)
7&8) mount and fasten inside bottom construction (there can be very little room) Then manually calibrate the bed using g-codes (see dreammaker forum, thanks Louis).
And it has been level for over 2 months now! I myself reversed the screws (unscrew from the top and insert them from the bottom) so they simply keep the heated bed in the correct x-y position.

comments.text:
The level screws tend to loosen because of the vibrations of the OLP.
18mm is the height the aluminum bed should be according to the DreamMaker team.
It is also the height the original firmware expects it to be.
If the bed would be at 50mm, you LOOSE some Z height.

author: dvhecke

title: Open Source Action Figure with 70 Points of Articulation (aka Dexter)

description.text:
Ever wanted an action figure with so many articulation points that it made all other action figures crawl back into their cardstock container? Well I present the open source action figure! This model offers hours of fun to assemble with your son or daughter. Imagine the parent that could print out an action figure, you would be a kids hero!! I made him pretty universal so he could be painted easy enough to be anyone. The head is joined so that maybe other heads could be made in the future.. The whole thing is held together with a little super glue and PLA spikes.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WqNxYHWpYko I have included the obj incase you wanted to mod him and I also made some breakdowns in stl format for you see how the joints are assembled. Dont let the picture fool you he stands 18 inches tall! Which somehow allows the wife to label it a doll because of that fact. I have to quickly correct her with Âaction figureÂ¦ uggg.... anyway. I hope you enjoy the build. Also I have included some of the techniques I use to create meshes in Blender and Zbrush http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pX5XdYoWPj0&list=PL9MUC-YxhJ6BylZ6HQJKZ-8Cs10Ny6Vrs&index=21 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wZaE5NMwXJM&list=PL9MUC-YxhJ6BylZ6HQJKZ-8Cs10Ny6Vrs&index=22 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kO-QQMQcokA&list=PL9MUC-YxhJ6BylZ6HQJKZ-8Cs10Ny6Vrs&index=23 Video regarding joint friction and surface blending tips
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aWDg5vWd2m8 Revision update 1.1
Added 4 sets of hands that are in a static pose.
Print - Cut away Island and support and mount to pivot via glue. Support is needed on the hands.

Tools youll need 1/16 Drill bit for the 1.8 Pla spikes
Drill bit for the 3mm Pla Spikes
Super Glue (I like gorilla super glue)
.1 Drill Bit for the fingers
22 gauge wire for the finger rivets
Elastic cord ---optional for the neck -- a 3mm pla spike works IMHO better -- if you make it a little longer it allows you to pivot at the neck base. (See head breakdown) See breakdown stls for assembly instructions A building tip-- after you add the glue and assemble grab a soldering iron and lightly tack the abs shells in spot weld fashion..... WARNING**** ABS is not good for you at all in smoke form. So please don't let the children do it... and use well ventilated area while holding breath........ (disclaimer-- holding breath might not do anything for your protection). Tip is optional! Another Tip
use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:108550 on the bottom of the feet. Really helps when you posing him to stand on all surfaces. Just a very thin coat with a brush. Or mask off and spray. How to work on the joints -- no file needed
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F_-mf8dUkPg&feature=youtu.be

comments.text:
A VERY VERY good stick to the build plate is required on this guy. Any lift and parts will not fit. I used more then 4 layers of hair spray each time.
All inner joints must be sanded ( I used 80 grit) and some filed to get a good fit.
The inner rotating hinge on the thighs have an asymmetrical hole which makes insertion of the glued together other side impossible. I had to clip the sides to get the part into the void.
comments.author: jasonwelsh

comments.text: If you sanded the inner joint he will fall down.. Only a tiny bit of that friction glue is required.  The kneecaps were just on different build plates that fit together to make it symmetrical. (updated)..    I never noticed that part because I just printed both build plates at once.   One side of the kneecap is thicker so if you stuck 2 thick sides together that would explain you having to sand it to death.
comments.author: TobyCWood

comments.text: I had to omit the rings in the joints. The joints simply worked better without them. I used the anti-grease material hot glue in the joint.

Took 5 tries to get the hand to print correctly in PLA. I suggest rather then tweaking packing density so that the infill on the tiny fingers does not jam the extruder... print the hand with zero infill. Worked ok with my Rep2.

comments.author: wenshidi

comments.text: The hands are the key to scale since they are the smallest. I was able to print a .75 scale hand and it looked like it would be ok to assemble.   I have a .5 head on my printer so sometimes it is a pain to print super small stuff.  By my calculations you would have to print him at 0.686 to get him to be 12 inches tall.   So scale the hand to .686 and print on your printer.  If you think you can assemble it the rest is easy to assemble once you print all the parts at .686.
comments.author: wenshidi

comments.text: The hands are higher resolution.  It takes awhile to rip them, I would also suggest the latest slicer.   But ya I have a slower machine hooked to the printers.  I cant use it to rip the hands either.  Find yourself some horsepower and you should be ok.

Hi Kids,
I would like to show you Banjiolin : a kind of little mixed banjo-violin.
I created this thing to participate of the challenge "Make It Loud". I though, if it is to make loud : it's better to play melody !!
So, I imagined a musical instrument based on the best them : Violin.
6 months ago, my friend Virgile bought a 3D printer (prusa i3) and a sample of each type of filament (wood, filaflex, extruder cleaning filament, ...). A spark sprung from my mind :
Why do not try using a flexible filament for strings and an extruder cleaning filament (kind of rough filament) as horsehair bow ??
I created this to test and validate the explained idea (printed by my friends Mat' and Virgile) and I asked to my daughter Fanette (better violinist than I know) to be the 'test pilot'.
All parts of this instrument are clippable, easy to assemble / disassemble and easy to tidy up
Enjoy :)

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

prusa

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

10-20%

Results After testing, it appears it is more a banjo than a violin... You can play in 'pizzicato' but not with the bow... rough filament doesn't produce a good vibration :(
However, you can tune 'strings' by different tension, it works ! You can play "music" :)
I used Sketchup 2015 (Free) to design Banjiolin.

title: Rear lens cap for CONTAX / YASHIKA lens mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are rear lens caps for CONTAX/YASHIKA lens mount.
The CONTAX lens of Carl Zeiss is great. But getting parts of them is difficult. So I made rear lens caps.
There are 4 types of outside.
  • with 'CONTAX' logo and with a grip.
  • with 'CONTAX' logo and no grip.
  • no logo and with a grip.
  • no logo and no grip.
    • Inside of any cap are same.
    The type 'no logo and no grip' is close to the original cap. I made the "CONTAX" logo. I took the picture that the "CONTAX" logo of my camera and traced it with 2D cad. So It is pretty accurate and it is not any font we can use. I printed this and tested with Planar 1.4/50, Distagon 2.8/28, and Vario-Sonnar 4/80-200.
    Mostly good and fit. But please take carefully to attach to the lens. Next I will make a rear lens cap for CONTAX G lens mount.
    Thanks and sorry for my poor english.

description.text:
Since my daugther's RC car crashed once to often in a wall, rock or other car the small front pin holding the car's body broke. The original Tamiya spare part is listed to be part of the "M parts", but I thought that I would have more fun designing my own replacement part using  FreeCAD. So here it is.
The Block was printed in 0,2mm layer height with one shell and 50% infill. The pin was printed with two shells and 50 infill but 0,1mm layer height.

author: spope

title: Printed holder for optical endstop (stripboard version)

description.text: Just a simple holder for a Gen7 optical endstop in the stripboard version (see http://reprap.org/wiki/Gen7_Endstop_1.3.1) For my custom Mendel90 I am using optical min endstops instead of mechanical max endstops. This holder ist used for fixing the y endstop to the base plate of the Mendel90. The stripboard is glued into the depression, then the holder is screwed on. The slot holes allow alignment of the holder, so the position of the slit of the photointerrupter can be adjusted. The scad file is mostly parametric, so can be easily adjusted for other pcb sizes, slot hole length etc.

Before printing, you can adjust the parameters in the scad file to match your stripboard or pcb. In the example stl the depression is 41 by 21 mm for a stripboard of 40 by 20 mm. The slot holes are 3.2mm for M3 screws and are 14mm in length.  
The holder was printed in PLA 3mm with a 0.5mm nozzle and a layer height of 0.4mm at 25% infill.  
After printing, attach the stripboard or pcb into the depression, e.g. with hot glue.  
You can then attach the assembled holder onto your device. The slot holes allow for some adjustment.

Simple conversion kit to make water changes in small fish tanks painless.
Just drill a 20mm hole in your acrylic tank with the bottom of the hole 3mm below your desired water level.
Slip one of the big washers over the outlet, apply silicone and insert the outlet through the tank from the inside.
Apply silicone to the outside of the hole and slip on the second washer to seal.
The big L pipe is an optional downspout.
There are gratings near the bottom of the tube to prevent escapes. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hcNrZk7C5H4

I designed this kit as a simplified version that is easily retrofitted to any small acrylic tank.  All that's required besides the kit is a suitable drill and some silicone.

title: Picavet for Action Cam 3 digital video camcorder

description.text: A Picavet is the preferred way of dangling a camera from a kite string. This one is designed to hold a small torch shaped video camera.  The Picavet cross itself will hold the camera pointing vertically down. This is OK, but produces rather boring films. The fork and legs can be added, to enable the camera to be pointed in any direction.

Drill holes, 3 to 3,5 mm as near to the Center of Gravity as you can. I fixed the forks to the legs with a rivet on one side (2 x 3mm washers and about 10mm of filament. Melt the ends over with a soldering iron. The other side has a 3mm machine screw and nut. So I could loosen and tighten the nut in the field, I glued the wingnut to the nut.
I'll add a bit of raw film here, as soon as i get a round toit.
You need about 4 meters of string to thread the picavet. For more details about see http://www.kaper.us/basics/BASICS_picavet.html

TL;DR - A Pan / Tilt servo mount for the Multiplex EasyStar foamy. http://www.mpx-easystar.de/index.php?id=2&L=1 The EasyStar is a great plane for First Person video flying, it's..
  • cheap
  • easy to assemble
  • easy to hand launch
  • very forgiving to fly
  • nearly unbreakable
  • very long dwell time with LiIon batteries and a brushless upgrade
  • able to carry a lot of weight
    • So here's a basic Pan/Tilt servo mount to velcro your camera of choice onto. I've sized the mounting cutouts for the cheap and incredibly common "Mystery" 9g transparent blue servos, and they work well. These are sold commercially for about $50, and my version costs me about .20c in MDF to cut..

This 'thing' is intended to be cut out of ordinary 3mm MDF fibreboard, 3mm balsa is also a possibility, even acrylic if you feel fancy. notches will need to be resized for thicker materials. The file is a more recent (improved) version than the built one in the photo's, but will assemble the same, and weigh a little less. First, fire the laser. :) Press-fit the side supports into the cockpit base, press the cockpit rear and cockpit front into place, and sit the assembly into the cockpit cavity on your EasyStar. I then place dots of CA glue onto the joins while pushing the assembly down to get the angles perfect, and spray it with CA kicker to set the base. As EasyStar's are a little variable in their manufacture, this makes sure everything fits. Mount the pan servo in the cockpit base from underneath (screws and servo body inside the plane). push fit a full-circle servo horn into the tilt base, and use some M2 sized screws to attach the horn to the base (CA glue will also work). Push the tilt sides into the pan base as shown. Mount the servo horn onto the pan servo using the provided screw, and make sure the assembly so far pans correctly. The tilt sides have "legs" that extend down to help support the tilt head, and I rub soap onto the bottoms of these legs to reduce friction. Oil doesn't work (it just swells the MDF). Install the tilt servo as shown, and put on a 2 bar horn. push on the pan top and glue the assembly so far. I use M3 x 6mm screws as "axles" for the camera platform, just using CA glue to fix them in place while holding it in position, it seems to work well. Add some stiff wire as a pushrod from the tilt servo horn to the camera platform horn and test it. Add a velcro dot the the camera platform and attach your camera. Should work like a bought one. :)

description.text:
This is an injection moldable version of BradDudenhoffer's Public Lab Spectrometer 3.0. The 3.0 version prints slightly better.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:49934
  • Print the three parts (the base and the body either plain or with the logo)
  • Attach a film grating to the upper side of the mount plate
  • insert the mount plate into the two sides, and screw together with 0-42 1/4" screws, or glue/acetone (if you use ABS).
  • Mount it to your phone
  • Use spectralworkbench.org to calibrate, save, and share your spectra. There is a native iOS app in the works but I can't say for sure when it will be released.
    • All parts have been NetFabbed and verified.
    This is the grating I have used for the prototype. It is the linear style with 1000lines per mm: tinyurl.com/9tjrz8r . You can also use the film off of a CD, DVD, or BluRay as seen here: publiclaboratory.org/tool/spectrometer License: CERN OHL v1.1 Public Lab contributors
    publiclaboratory.org/tool/spectrometer

comments.text: I've managed to split this model in half too avoiding have all of the support material underneath. If your printer is calibrated properly you can then just stick the two halves together. A full model in 0.1mm layer height with support took me 23 hours, i'v split it into two and each side is 6 hours for me now. A saving of 11 hours, will post a remake of this with the included files :) If there is any issues with my remake (if your license doesn't agree with the share, then please notify me and I will remove it) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2300259
comments.author: samuel235

comments.text: What program did you use to split the model. I have been looking for a good one and most of the time the other programs just crashed since the model was to big. Also this was a reshare. So since I was not notified I don't have an issue with the remake. But if I get notified I will let you know.
comments.author: samuel235

comments.text: NetFabb. I tried most other things other than MeshMixer as i have no clue at all how to use that but NetFabb allowed me to slice it in half without moaning about memory overloads and everything else. The crashes you and I were seeing are simply because we're using programs that are not specifically made to handle STL files, but rather made to be able to use them, not designed from the ground up for that sole purpose where NetFabb is.
comments.author: andku85

comments.text: Thanks for the info. I ended up adding additional splits. So not just a top and bottom but a front and back version as well.
comments.author: samuel235

comments.text: Are you planning on printing those now or just made the models for people? I'm thinking that it would be slightly less quality on the front and back splits, please let me know how you're getting on with them in terms of quality. Are you using a 0.4mm nozzle too?
comments.author: andku85

comments.text: I have been emailed about different slicing. i have been asked for a top and bottom and a front and back. everyone has different printers and all want one way to print. since you gave me the better option to slice the model i just uploaded them all. and included a 3ds model so people can work on the model.
comments.author: samuel235

comments.text: Ahh okay, so they were only from requests. Thanks for explaining :) I don't suppose you know how to add a bottom to convert the model from a shell to a solid object do you? This would be much quicker to print that way. I've had an order for 5 of these and i'm on number 2 at the moment. I've been on NetFabb for hours yesterday attempting to add a bottom to this.

comments.text: I am still looking into that. if you find a solution let me know. Also I hope that you are not selling these. or at least not selling them for a huge mark up. If you charge for material and ware and tear on the printer i guess that is fine. but these models are meant to be free.

comments.text: If you click on "Things Details" and under the "Summary" there are "Print Settings" and it says you need to print with supports and a 10% infill. Did you not set that up when you started to print? Normally when supports are selected in the slicer it usually adds them where it is needed. comments.text: Yes. 14 hours later its finished. I don't see why they're not modelled as a solid and then printed with low infil. Making them hollow on the model means infill has to go inside of the model for the simple fact of the small turret on the top. So I would have modelled it either solid and then printed with very low infill OR made the turret at the top require no support.

description.text:
While staying at someone's house for a while, my wife found the shower difficult to use.  The Grohe shower head is one of those hand held types, but the wall bracket did not match the shower head correctly, and held it at the wrong angle....the shower head was perpetually pointing in towards the wall.  So to shower, you had to constantly hold the shower head in your hand the whole time.  My first thought was that that bracket was mounted upside down or something, but no luck.  It must just be mismatched.  So, I designed and printed a new bracket that holds the shower head at the right angle.
After I was done, I noticed other similar OpenSCAD objects on Thingiverse, that I probably could have modified, but I made a new one in Solidworks since I did not search until afterwards.

Print it out, hang it up, and enjoy your wife's gratitude (and saving $29.95 on buying a new shower head system just to correct the bracket).
Another daughter and daddy success!

I realize we're well past the "beefy arms" fad that swept Thingiverse for like two weeks, but... I made a couple of these as speaker gifts for pdxruby.org, and then I just kept making more. A few notes:

  • This looks especially nice in a translucent filament.

  • I typically print with supports in Cura set to "everywhere", but you can probably get away without this.

  • The bottom is truncated so that the thing will (a) stick to the build plate and (b) stand up on its own. If you're having adhesion problems (probably with the point of the gem, which has the smallest surface area), you have a few choices:
    • add a brim
    • enlarge the print
    • drop the print a few more mm below the build plate (i.e., cut off more of the bottom)
    • copy and edit the source parts on TinkerCAD: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1bjLE3DICk3-gem-with-beefy-arms

Up till now, I have had the glue bottles in my workshop standing in old glasses to get them to stand upside down. It has been a bit of a nuisance, since the bottom of the glass was too small to make a stable stand, and the top of the glass was too small for the bottles to fit tightly and therefore for them to stand straight. 
Now I have made a new glue bottle cap that is so big that the bottles can stand safely on it. I have three different kinds of glue - all from Dana and all in similar bottles. I have no idea if this is a world wide glue bottle standard.... I have also uploaded the cap test, if you want to do a test print before wasting filament on the big cap.
The bottom of the new cap is 75 mm, which is the same as the bottom of the bottle, which again means that the bottle now stands equally stable whether it is upside up or down.

This is a card holder that fits Catan cards. Glue three of them side by side and you've got yourself six slots in which to vertically place resource and development cards. I kept having troubles printing out the really nice one by MaxGjr: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:399805 This smaller one prints way more easily for me. December 6th, 2015 update: added another version that allows you to vertically display the Largest Army and Longest Road cards behind all the others. It also features the option to connect them by gluing or bolting together (thread a 190mm x 4mm rod at both ends) January 1st, 2016 update: if bolts and glue ain't your thang for bonding these parts together, tejawood made a nice snap-together version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1238868 January 27th, 2016 update: Added a 3rd version - it features extruded bumps which allows cards to sit more upright and not lay against cards behind them.

title: Prusa i3 Y Axis End Stop Clip on Mount for M10

description.text:
This is a clip on Prusa i3 Y Axis end stop mount. Im sure others exist but I got tired of looking for one that would fit my end stops and was clip on.
The part accommodates an end stop that is 22mm high by 6mm wide. The depth is approx 9mm so plenty of room.
I printed this with a 0.3mm layer height at 25% infill and results were very good. The clips should be a little bit hard to press on so it stays firmly in place. I have included the SolidWorks file as well incase anyone wants to make some changes.
You may want to orient this on your slicer so that the m10 openings face upward - this way you wont have to deal with printing overhangs.

A Pressure-Volume-Temperature diagram for substances that expand upon freezing (such as water). On the labeled diagram, axes and phases are labeled, though it may be difficult to read the phases.
I've found that this diagram is quite helpful in thermodynamics. Although it's not completely accurate, it's close enough that you should be able to tell what it's supposed to look like. (The tiny erroneous edge along Solid+Liquid never shows up in a print, as far as I can tell, but Inventor just couldn't remove it.)

Printer:

M3D Micro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

5-10%

Notes: For the sake of the text, print it with the pressure axis vertical. This also gives the fastest print time.

author: MrMaso

title: Drop-in Build Plate Upgrade for Makergear M2

description.text: These are replacement HBP corner pads for the Makergeare M2 that secure the build plate with spring force, eliminating the binder clips. Use with either the stock glass build plate or a Zebra Plate. Update: I'm now using this also with a beadblasted MIC6 1/4" aluminum plate (from jimc of the Makergear forum), with chamfers filed into the plate. This works well. Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NU7xbhOOjm0&feature=youtu.be The two needed springs are McMaster-Carr part number 1986K64. These are optional if the parts are printed in polycarbonate (esun ePC or Polymaker Polycarbonate-Plus). A complete parts list and assembly instructions are here: http://lightsmithscientific.com/justine-haupt/M2/DropInBuildPlate/MakergearM2DropInBuildPlate_AssemblyInstructions.pdf Material note: I originally made these in PETG but have since discovered Polycarbonate (esun ePC) and have reprinted them in that material. The photo of the parts sitting on the bed are the new polycarbonate ones. The black ones shown in all the other photos were PETG. Also, it was observed on the Makergear forum that printing these in polycarbonate may be necessary for long term resistance to the 100C bed temperature used when running with polycarbonate anyway.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

50-70%

Notes: See assembly instructions for more detail. These were originally printed in PETG, which worked well, and reprinted in ePC (polycarbonate) to run the bed at very high temperatures. It appears that the McMaster springs are quite unnecessary with the ePC versions. I'll wait a few months to be sure they're not loosing their springiness before being sure the metal springs aren't needed.

comments.text: Made this and LOVE it! You are awesome, such a great design!
